title: Semantics – Interoperability – Integration A multi-faceted problem
segmentation: My name is Yannis Kazio plus I work for a company based in Athens, Greece, but not only called European dynamics and what I'll try to do is introduce you to what we see from our point of view.
And going beyond that, to give some deeper thoughts on what interoperability and buying large integration is about and what it involves, which goes a little bit beyond what we may think.
To give you an idea of an environment that is not to say roughly what how good we are, good, we're not.
What we do is we operate full of large international organizations.
One of them is the European Commission, obviously another one is bigger be in Parliament Europol Eurocontrol.
All these organizations, they have been our clients and our own plans in various occasions.
As you can see we have come across things that have to have some cross border interoperability, cross border functionality and so on.
So it is from this point of view that I will introduce first one problem that is quite important sometimes overlooked but has played quite a big part at four which.
We need solutions and these solutions have to do with semantics.
Custom.
It happens and we have done quite a few applications in customs in accordance to common rules and common specifications started by the Commission.
In fact, early 2000 by text, so they started trying to formalize customs to find a common way of doing things and to implement the exchanges of structural messages between Member States.
These are done today through a network that is a private network called CCN.
And this network has the ability to send messages from one country to another.
These messages are defined.
In a complex functional and technical way, and they are able to carry semantics in them, which however are not defined in India in an Inter in a direct way.
They are defined in an external way, but this is not something structured like an ontology, but they are contained in accompanying documents.
So to find what something means in some message or a combination of two things, you have to look at the relevant document.
It is obvious that you have to do this manually.
Yourself, that is, that takes time and in the end you will find a solution.
But this is relatively far from optimal.
Functional areas covered.
Keep on increasing.
Currently transit export, import are covered and one or two others.
But a very important issue is that important things like.
Risk analysis, which is the basis on which customs work, is not covered at all from the from any point of view, let alone semantics.
Now the messaging system works on XML primarily.
There's one or two installations in that effect.
Well defined formats, as I said, interactive defined semantics.
You can find entities appearing under different names under different structures.
If you did your work, however you will.
Find sense in there.

And primarily every individual state has its own application that handles these things in these messages and what it does with these messages is included purely in the application logic of their particular state, that is.
Semantics is not application independent in this case.
Despite all these things, I said the basic system works.
Now let's go to something more important.
Risk detection of fraud things going through customs.
What do we do about them?
Whether they are within the Union, whether they are within the Union and exchange states, whether they get out of the Union and get out of it through some root?
As you can realize.
This exchange is quite critical.
Customs are not able to check everything that goes through them.
It is a very small percentage.
They can have a look at and they never.
They almost never do it randomly or the random percentage is extremely small.
How they do it they guided by risk.
That is by information they have gathered either about the past of some trader, the past of some route, or information given by somebody.
That may point to something that is suspicious.
Now, the percentages of what is checked.
What are the things that are checked are very, very small.
There are the order of 5%, four percent, 3% depending on the situation, but certainly not much more than that.
As you can realize the better way, you can estimate risk.
The better you can do in this field, and the smaller the percentage goes.
When it goes down for various reasons, the better your risk assessment should be and the more accurate.
Now the implications are pretty pretty important.
First of all, public safety and health probably the most important second equally important security you can imagine a suspicious cargo going through.
From the outside of EU through one country through another through another and ending up in another.
You can imagine the same similar cargo going through one country going up to Sweden and coming back to a country that is neighboring.
They can't enable to their country the original country.
Why has this route been chosen?
Nothing happens in between is just a root.
You can obviously think that these things can be suspicious.
Yes, they are.
So far, however, we have no structure standard messages to exchange risk related information, and even worse, even if we did, we don't know what these things mean.
Example, what's a suspicious trader?
What is suspicious root?
Isn't that when I go from one country to the other and I take an intermediate step that is at the other end of the Union?
Is this a suspicious route maybe?
What are the entities related to this risk?
Are we talking about financial risk, health risk, safety risk?
By and large, they're not even behavioral models that can define this type of behavior, and this obviously cannot be communicated right now.
This knowledge, which is very important, stays within the authorities, the customs authorities of each state.
The only thing that has been defined in a relatively abstract way, a common risk criteria.
Therefore you can see here that what we don't have is we have no definition of entities related to risk, and we cannot under any circumstances communicate this in a semantically meaningful way.
Let alone be this being identified by machines directly.
Well, recent scandals in the food chain you may have heard of.
The horse meat scandal.
The dioxin scandal before that and others.
You can imagine how.
Much less danger could have existed had state authorities.
After having experiences of this type and having noukas things could if they could communicate them to other states.
And if they could do this in a meaningful way, right now we don't even know what risk is, and this obviously has to be defined at the pan European level.
Now I haven't given an example.
Hopefully if you agree with this.
The situation is ace it.
A task of just sitting down and doing some work and agreeing together into some terminology that is common into the connections it has.
Doing dictionaries and agreeing with them doing perhaps taxonomies and sitting down doing all the nitty gritty and solving the problem.
Is it so easy.
Well, the answer to this is no.
And why?
We do manage today to have database interoperability.
We managed to be able to do cross database searches, integration of web services at some level.
Through to do this, we use ontologies.
That is, logical axioms that relate to predicates of interest.
Without these, a theory of Analogic, if I tell you in abstract terms.
We have achieved.
Generally, a higher level of abstraction for data modeling.
And we also can do data export by what we have today.
We can do data translation, we can.
Set of queries and we can even unify to some extent between in dependently developed database designs, logical, physical and so on.
However, when we want to move towards real data integration and this will definitely entail both interoperability as well as integration, which is a bit of a wider sense.
The limitations are here and we don't have an answer for them.
Festival.
If we have data datasets that have semantics, if they're given by different ontologies, they certainly require integration of 'em.
We achieve these things today by trying to do mapping spamming ontologies.
We try to do mergers.
We tried to do vocabularies of the top level and so on.
However the real problem into integrating ontologies proper is.
That we have to integrate logics logics in which they are expressed and underneath those logics we have schemas that describe structure.
They do this in different languages and they do this in data models that are different.
Nation, object oriented and so on.
Now.
What we really face is a problem that.
Requires at this high level of theory, end of abstraction to have.
A representation independent and logical formalism, independent tools and ways to work with this is the heart of the problem at a high level of what?
Which will really give us an acceptable solution to semantic integration.

Now this requires us to go beyond what we think we can achieve today requires us to go into higher levels of abstraction and mathematical sophistication, to be exact metamathematical that is used, theories that are representation independent and logical formalism independent.
This leads us directly to theories such as category theories or theories of institutions by various researchers, and so on.
What do I want to say by always?
Do not be deceived, we will not achieve.
Quite a satisfactory way to do semantic integration if we do not combine the three things.
At least that's my humble opinion.
If we don't combine policy, that is, they will to go along these things.
They will do agree on common terminologies.
They we do agree on the connections that we do agree on meanings.
For example, in the interchange of government documents between different states, there's one case.
If we don't combine suitable technology to go with it, we can say we have a lot of it right now.
Fortunately and finally, and perhaps most important in this case, if we don't join this join up.
These two things by research.
Now this.
Circle ellipse that you see here.
We're not very good at this in the European Union.
In fact we I would say that we're relatively bad if you look at the percentages spent by the US and by Japan, and perhaps tomorrow by China.
the European Union is lowest of the low, is about half or even less than that.
Obviously.
A manifestation of this is what happened in Horizon 2020.
They started talking about 100.
Billion plus it ended up in 280 or a little bit less than that.

Therefore, at European Union level, I would say that to be able to solve these things and in the end to serve the Single market ending the end to serve better unification and a Better Business area therefore.
Improve the lives of all we have to combine these three things in a much better way than what we do today.
Thank you.
